verses.verse: ((1 A prophecy of the destruction of Damascus and Ephraim,7 calamity moveth to repentance.) ) The (Read Isa. 13:1.) burden of (The chief city of Syria.) Damascus. Behold, Damascus is taken away from being a city, for it shall be a ruinous heap.
The cities of (It was a country of Syria by the river Arnon.) Aroer shall be forsaken: they shall be for the flocks: for they shall lie there, and none shall make them afraid.

The munition also shall cease from (It seemeth that the Prophet would comfort the Church in declaring the destruction of these two kings of Syria and Israel, when as they had conspired the overthrow of Judah.) Ephraim, and the kingdom from Damascus, and the remnant of Aram shall be as the (The ten tribes gloried in their multitude and alliance with other nations: therefore he saith that they shall be brought down, and the Syrians also.) glory of the children of Israel, saith the Lord of hosts.
And in that day the glory of (Meaning, of the ten tribes, which boasted themselves of their nobility, prosperity, strength and multitude.) Jacob shall be made clean.

And it shall be as when the harvest man gathereth (As the abundance of corn doth not fear the harvest men that should cut it down: no more shall the multitude of Israel make the enemies to shrink, whom God shall appoint to destroy them.) the corn, and reapeth the ears with his arm, and he shall be as he that gathereth the ears in the valley of (Which valley was plentiful and fertile.) Rephaim.

Yet a gathering of grapes shall (Because God would have his covenant stable, he promiseth to reserve some of this people, and to bring them to repentance.) be left in it: as the shaking of an olive tree, two or three berries are in the top of the upmost boughs, and four or five in the high branches of the fruit thereof, saith the Lord God of Israel.

At that day shall a man look to his (He showeth that Godâ€™s corrections ever bring forth some fruit, and cause his to turn from their sins, and to humble themselves to him.) maker, and his eyes shall look to the holy one of Israel.
And he shall not look to the altars, the works of his own hands, neither shall he look to those things which his own fingers have made, as groves and images.

In that day shall the cities of their strength be as the forsaking of boughs and branches, which (As the Canaanites left their cities when God did place the Israelites there, so the cities of Israel shall no more be able to defend their inhabitants than bushes, when God shall send the enemy to plague them.) they did forsake, because of the children of Israel, and there shall be desolation.

Because thou hast forgotten the God of thy salvation, and hast not remembered the God of thy strength, therefore shalt thou set pleasant plants, and shalt graft strange (Which are excellent, and brought out of other countries.) vine branches.

In the day shalt thou make thy plant to grow, and in the morning shalt thou make thy seed to flourish: but the harvest shall be gone in the day (As the Lord threateneth the wicked in his Law, Lev. 26:16.) of possession, and there shall be desperate sorrow.

(The Prophet lamenteth, considering the horrible plague that was prepared against Israel by the Assyrians, which were infinite in number, and gathered of many nations.) Ah, the multitude of many people, they shall make a sound like the noise of the sea: for the noise of the people shall make a sound like the noise of mighty waters.

The people shall make a sound like the noise of many waters: but God shall (He addeth this for the consolation of the faithful which were in Israel.) rebuke them, and they shall flee far off, and shall be chased as the chaff of the mountains before the wind, and as a rolling thing before the whirlwind.

And lo, in the evening there is (He compareth the enemies the Assyrians to a tempest, which riseth overnight, and in the morning is gone.) trouble: but afore the morning it is gone. This is the portion of them that spoil us, and the lot of them that rob us.
